subject: Re: Best Practice for Batch Load Tests
msgSnippet: Thats what I figured. Thank you for the input; I will likely proceed as you have stated. I m looking forward to other opinions as well. Thank you. John ...
messageBody:
Thats what I figured. Thank you for the input; I will likely proceed
as you have stated.

I'm looking forward to other opinions as well.

Thank you.
John

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "David Saff" <saff@...> wrote:
>
> The advantage of using two separate files is that your test data better
> reflects the intent of what you want to test, and you can run and
debug the
> tests in isolation from each other.
>
> I can't think of a huge advantage of loading both at the same time,
unless
> you get a really big performance benefit (even then, I might do the
above
> instead).
>
> David Saff
>
> On 11/8/06, johnpitchko <john.pitchko@...> wrote:
> >
> > Hello,
> >
> > I am writing some tests which will test our batch load processes.
> > These processes basically load files through our middleware and verify
> > the output in Oracle.
> >
> > My question is related to best practices. In my current situation, I
> > want to write two tests:
> > 1) is a standard operation test where it loads a file and makes sure
> > everything was sent properly to Oracle.
> > 2) is a specialized test where it loads a file and checks to see if
> > the site code was capitalized in Oracle.
> >
> > So my question is this, should I use individual files for each test
> > (i.e., one file containing many lines of site data for the first test
> > and then a seperate file containing a single line with a lowercase
> > site code) and load each file at the start of each test, or should I
> > combine the data from both into a single file and load that before all
> > the tests are run (using a @BeforeClass)?
> >
> > Thank you in advance.
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > Yahoo! Groups Links
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>
